stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on creating and brainstorming assets for Course 14, the 'craft level'. He also showcased significant progress on Course 13, including a live performance test on N64 hardware. Throughout the stream, he discussed his game design philosophy, a potential sponsorship deal, and his YouTube content strategy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze states that due to memory throughput optimizations, the N64's RSP (graphics co-processor) is now the primary performance bottleneck, not the CPU. A contributor named Sauraen is working on new RSP optimizations.
development_findings.quote: The RSP became the bottleneck, at least on my end. So I no longer think the CPU is that much overpowered compared to the RSP.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is a 'craft level' themed around materials like cardboard, crayons, and plastic cups. Star concepts include drawing a star with a crayon and platforming inside a cardboard box.
While testing Course 13 on N64 hardware, Kaze identified that an excess of clouds caused the framerate to drop to 25 FPS but is confident he can easily resolve it.
development_findings.quote: I can very easily increase the FPS by just reducing the amount of clouds. That would be no issue at all.

development_findings.summary: The release strategy involves an initial version compatible with both emulators and N64 hardware, followed by a later version focused exclusively on N64, challenging emulator developers to keep up.
development_findings.quote: My plan is we release version 1... And then 1.2 is only N64. Because at that point we have enough emulator compatibility that we can just say, fuck it, we're making an N64 game. And emulators will then technologically have to catch up with the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is brainstorming pun-based brand names for crayons in the craft level, with 'Craytendo', 'Artendo', and 'Koopa's Tail' being the leading contenders.
The game's overworld is planned to be 'Yoshi's fruit islands,' with the player exploring deeper into the island over time. Zeina is creating concept sketches for it.
Kaze criticizes the overuse of red coins in ROM hacks as an uncreative way to meet a required star count, contrasting with his goal of creating more unique objectives.
development_findings.quote: I must put red coins in my level because I need eight eight stars and six seven stars in my level and the red coins are just such a cheap way to do them without actually being creative.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong anti-advertisement philosophy, believing ads surcharge consumers. He is considering a Raid Shadow Legends sponsorship with the explicit goal of subverting it, for example, by following the ad with hours of mundane content.
context_findings.quote: Generally, I never take sponsorships unless I can think of a way to like fuck them over.

context_findings.summary: Kaze advises aspiring game developers to create many small games quickly to accelerate their learning process and move past the initial phase of making bad games.
context_findings.quote: My advice to get people getting into game development is always make as many games as possible as fast as possible. So you learn because your first 100 games or so are just going to suck ass.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on his earlier design philosophy for 'Last Impact', which prioritized implementing interesting ideas immediately over ensuring they were fun, driven by a desire to not be perceived as lazy.
context_findings.quote: When I made Last Impact, really my thought was never can I make this fun. It was always just I have an idea, I'll put it in. I didn't even double check if it was a good idea.

context_findings.summary: Kaze critiques a perceived mindset within parts of the ROM hacking community where players endure unenjoyable game design, viewing it as a sign of a flawed approach to game creation that prioritizes mechanics over the player's experience.
context_findings.quote: Six out of eight rats is like geek mental illness. It's like I must play Mario 64 hacks and I am miserable when I play them but there is this patch that makes it slightly less miserable for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze lives in Canada with his wife, Zeina, and is a permanent resident. He expresses a strong dislike for his home country, Germany, citing high taxes, bureaucracy, and unfriendly people as reasons for leaving.

Kaze plans to increase his YouTube content, specifically creating more analytical videos like his successful 'The Problem with the Grass' video, as a way to increase his income and build PR for his future original game.

biobak.summary: Biobak is actively optimizing levels, having removed 400 polygons from the main area by replacing placeholder trees with better, lower-poly versions.
biobak.quote: Rearmament will increase a little, but so far main area has 400 fewer polis and a shit ton of materials and overall removed.

biobak.summary: Kaze expects the visual quality of Course 13 to significantly improve once Biobak applies his artistic skills to it.
Biobak is currently working on preparing the demo for the first course of the game.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for finishing the outside area of Course 13.
She playtested the movement physics in Course 13, and her ability to navigate it well gave Kaze confidence in the design's intuitiveness.
Zeina is contributing design ideas, such as suggesting 'Koopa Colors' for a crayon brand name and creating sketches for the overworld.

key_stories.title: The Raid Shadow Legends Sponsorship Negotiation
key_stories.summary: Kaze navigates a sponsorship offer from Raid Shadow Legends by using AI to handle the financial negotiation and planning a troll video to satisfy the contract while subverting the sponsor. This story showcases his principles on advertising and his creative, humorous approach to business challenges.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze received a sponsorship offer from Raid Shadow Legends, a company whose advertising practices conflict with his personal principles.
key_stories.process: Instead of negotiating himself, Kaze used ChatGPT to draft a maximalist negotiation email. He then planned the sponsored video content to be a one-minute ad followed by hours of mundane content ('every visible wall in Super Mario 64').
key_stories.outcome: The negotiation is ongoing. Kaze has a clear plan to create a subversive sponsored video that fulfills the contract's letter but mocks its spirit, aligning with his anti-ad stance.
key_stories.key_quote: I legit just went to chat GPT and told it make me as much money as possible. And it just spat out that text and I just sent that to Raid Shadow Legends.

key_stories.title: Evolution of Design Philosophy
key_stories.summary: Kaze reflects on his past design philosophy for 'Last Impact,' where he prioritized adding ideas over making them fun, driven by a fear of being lazy. He contrasts this with his current, more mature approach, which focuses on the holistic player experience and critiques the 'miserable' design he sees elsewhere in the community.
key_stories.challenge: Reflecting on his past work, Kaze contrasts his previous design philosophy with his current one for 'Return to Yoshi's Island'.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained that for 'Last Impact,' he was driven by a fear of being lazy, causing him to add any idea he had without filtering. He now critiques the 'mechanics over feeling' approach he sees in some ROM hacks, indicating a shift towards a more player-centric and holistic design methodology.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has evolved from a designer who prioritized implementing 'interesting' ideas without question to one who considers the overall player experience, including fun and presentation, more deeply.
key_stories.key_quote: When I made Last Impact, really my thought was never can I make this fun. It was always just I have an idea, I'll put it in... I didn't want to be some lazy dude who doesn't put the things he wanted in this game in.

key_stories.title: Live Performance Triage of Course 13
key_stories.summary: While showcasing progress on Course 13, Kaze performs a live performance test on N64 hardware. He discovers the framerate drops below his 30 FPS target, quickly identifies the cause as too many cloud models, and confidently states the simple fix, demonstrating his technical workflow.
key_stories.challenge: Course 13, a visually complex level, was suffering from performance issues, dropping to 25 FPS on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: During the stream, Kaze loaded Course 13 on an N64 via a flashcart to test its real-world performance. He observed the framerate drops, immediately diagnosed the issue as an overabundance of cloud models, and identified the straightforward solution.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze is confident that the performance can be easily brought back to a stable 30 FPS or higher by simply reducing the number of cloud objects in the level.
key_stories.key_quote: I want at least 30 FPS. We're in the 50s. No, we're still in the 30s. 25 there. I can very easily increase the FPS by just reducing the amount of clouds.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that Zeina is working on the outside of Course 13, Biobak is optimizing models and preparing the demo, and Kaze is creating new assets. He jokes about not employing Biobak.
questions: Can you describe the typical workflow for a level? For example, how does an idea go from your concept to something Biobak refines visually?
How do you coordinate tasks and exchange feedback with Zeina and Biobak without a formal studio structure?
How does Zeina's feedback, like on the Course 13 physics, get integrated into the development process?

open_questions.context: Kaze explains that after optimizing memory throughput, the N64's RSP (graphics co-processor) has become the main performance bottleneck, and that a contributor named Sauraen is working on it.
questions: Could you explain in more detail what Sauraen's work on the RSP involves?
What new visual or gameplay possibilities could these RSP optimizations unlock for the project?
How did the collaboration with Sauraen begin?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the overworld theme is 'Yoshi's fruit islands' and that Zeina has been creating sketches for it, but no concrete designs were shown.
questions: Can you describe the vision for the 'Yoshi's fruit islands' overworld? What will the player's progression through it feel like?
What role is Zeina playing in the overworld's design, and how are her sketches being used to build it?
Are there any unique mechanics planned for the overworld itself?

open_questions.context: Kaze passionately critiques a mindset in the ROM hacking community, using the example of a '6 out of 8 rats' patch for an unnamed hack, which he feels exemplifies players forcing themselves through miserable experiences.
questions: You mentioned the '6 out of 8 rats' patch as an example of 'geek mental illness' in game design. Could you elaborate on what that phenomenon represents to you?
How does that design philosophy you're critiquing contrast with the experience you want players to have in 'Return to Yoshi's Island'?
What makes a challenge 'fun' versus 'miserable' in a Mario 64 hack?
